docs.lead_paragraph: With 19 months to go before the elections and no opponent in sight, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign is nonetheless warning her political supporters that she is the prime target of ''the right-wing attack machine.'' In a fund-raising e-mail message sent out on Thursday, Mrs. Clinton's campaign also said her critics were preparing an advertising campaign against her similar to the one orchestrated by Swift Boat Veterans for Truth, a group that attacked Senator John Kerry's Vietnam service during the presidential election.
docs.abstract: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign sends fundraising e-mail message warning supporters that she will be target of 'right-wing attack machine' during her re-election campaign in 2006; photo (M)

headline.main: Clinton Supporters Gear Up Against 'Swift Boat' Tactics

docs.snippet: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign is warning her political supporters that she is the prime target of "the right-wing attack machine."...

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton called for the deployment of additional foreign soldiers in Afghanistan Thursday during a Thanksgiving visit to American troops here. Senator Clinton, citing recent attacks on aid workers, said reinforcements from the United States or NATO were needed to increase security. ''I believe we need more troops,'' she said. ''I don't think we have an adequate number of troops to do what needs to be done.''
docs.abstract: Sen Hillary Rodham Clinton calls for deployment of additional foreign soldiers in Afghanistan during Thanksgiving visit to American troops there; cites recent attacks on aid workers in asking for reinforcements from United States or NATO (M)

headline.main: Senator Clinton, in Afghanistan, Calls for More Foreign Troops

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton urged the federal government yesterday to consider flying air patrols over New York State's nuclear power plants. In a letter to Donald H. Rumsfeld, the secretary of defense, Senator Clinton urged patrols over the Indian Point, Nine Mile and Gina nuclear power plants. The letter, also sent to the Department of Homeland Security, noted federal warnings this week that operatives of Al Qaeda might try to hijack cargo jets from Canada, Mexico and the Caribbean and fly them into nuclear plants. The Sept. 11 hijackers, Senator Clinton wrote, ''were believed to have flown over or nearby the Indian Point reactors on their way down the Hudson River.'' Stacey Stowe (NYT)
docs.abstract: Sen Hillary Rodham Clinton urges federal government to fly air patrols over Indian Point, Nine Mile and Gina nuclear power plants in New York, noting recent warnings that Al Qaeda might try to hijack cargo jets and fly them into nuclear plants (S)

byline.original: By Stacey Stowe (NYT); Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

docs.lead_paragraph: A joint team from the Nepalese and Indian armies is to climb Mount Everest and clear rubbish left by previous climbers, officials said. The expedition, with 12 climbers from each side, will mark the 50-year anniversary of the first climb to the 29,028-foot peak. The team members left Kathmandu for the Everest base camp. A record 20 teams are to attempt to scale Everest this spring to celebrate the first conquest by Sir Edmund Hillary, left, and Tenzing Norgey Sherpa on May 29, 1953.
docs.abstract: Clean-up expedition begins marking fiftieth anniversary of first successful climb to summit of 29,028-foot Mount Everest; group of 12 Nepalese and 12 Indian military personnel will clear away trash and debris left by other expeditions; record 20 teams are attempting climb this year in celebration of inaugural accomplishment by Sir Edmond Hillary and sherpa Tenzing Norgay on May 29, 1953; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The occupational health center of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine in Manhattan will begin offering free health examinations this summer -- at federal government expense -- to thousands of people who worked or volunteered at ground zero. The $12 million program, which was announced yesterday by Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton at a joint news conference with hospital physicians and administrators, will provide full health screenings, including X-rays and specialized breathing tests.
docs.abstract: Sen Hillary Rodham Clinton announces $12 million federal program offering free health examinations to thousands of people who worked or volunteered at ground zero; occupational health center of Mt Sinai School of Medicine will conduct exams (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Proposed legislation announced today would allow an American victim of state-sponsored terrorism who wins a civil judgment against another country -- Iran, Iraq or Libya, for example -- to collect money from assets of that country that have been frozen in the United States. The measure, sponsored by a bipartisan group of five senators, is opposed by the Bush administration, which contends that the State Department needs to control frozen assets of foreign countries as a diplomatic tool. In fighting the bill, the Bush administration is adopting the same stance as the Clinton administration before it.
docs.abstract: Bill sponsored by bipartisan group of senators would allow American victim of state-sponsored terrorism who wins civil judgment against another country to collect money from that country's frozen assets in US; Bush administration is opposed, saying State Department needs to control frozen assets of countries like Iran or Iraq as diplomatic tool; several bills involving Iran outlined; one is co-sponsored by Hillary Rodham Clinton (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton met yesterday with relatives of Sept. 11 terrorist attack victims, and called for changes in the plan to distribute financial compensation from the federal government. The changes Mrs. Clinton suggested included clarifying that same-sex partners of victims would be compensated for their losses and ensuring that the families of illegal immigrants who died would not be deported if they sought awards.
docs.abstract: Sen Hillary Rodham Clinton meets with relatives of Sept 11 terrorist attack victims and calls for changes in plan to distribute money from federal government; proposes compensation for same-sex partners of victims and seeks assurances that families of illegal immigrants who died will not be deported if they seek awards; also proposes eliminating rule that survivors seeking compensation for injuries must prove they sought medical attention within 24 hours of disaster (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two operators of pornographic Web sites that advertised memberships for less than $50, or free, but billed consumers for hundreds of dollars in international long-distance telephone calls, have agreed to settle charges that they violated federal law, the Federal Trade Commission said. When users tried to view pornographic images on the sites, their computers were connected to an outside server using a ''dialer'' program that disconnected them from their Internet service provider and reconnected them through long-distance telephone calls to Ghana and Madagascar. Hillary Sheinkin, of Ladson, S.C., was barred from using aliases to register other Web sites, and must pay a $10,000 fine to the government. And Charlo Barbosa, of Vancouver, British Columbia, agreed to pay more than $26,000 in consumer redress for bilking people out of hundreds of dollars in telephone charges through a similar, but separate Internet operation.
docs.abstract: Hillary Sheinkin and Charlo Barbosa, operators of pornographic Web sites that advertised memberships for less than $50, or free, but billed consumers for hundreds of dollars in international long-distance telephone calls, agree to settle FTC charges that they violated federal law (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A small island off the coast of Puerto Rico has captured the national, if not global, stage and provoked a surprising degree of activism. Remember when most people couldn't even pronounce Vieques, much less point it out on a map? The fate of this island's inhabitants -- the Navy, as most people know by now, practices dropping its bombs there -- has sucked in a hodgepodge of big names from the political, environmental and entertainment worlds, from Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and Mario M. Cuomo to the actor Benicio Del Toro and the singer Ricky Martin.
docs.abstract: Vieques, small island off coast of Puerto Rico, captures national stage and provokes suprising degree of activism; fate of this island's inhabitants has sucked in hodgepodge of big names from political, environmental and entertainment worlds; photos of protesters, and of Sen Hillary Rodham Clinton, who visits jailed protesters (M)
